title: 112_hr6319
content: The "Startup Innovation Credit Act of 2012" allows certain startup companies to receive treatment for research credit. The "Startup Innovation Credit Act of 2012" allows qualified small businesses to treat the payroll tax credit portion of the credit as a credit allowed under section 3111(f) if it does not exceed $250,000. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for entities and individuals to qualify for certain tax benefits based on their gross receipts for the taxable year. The text chunk outlines the limitation and election rules for partnerships or S corporations regarding tax benefits based on gross receipts. Aggregation rules apply for determining limitations and gross receipts for entities under common control. The text chunk outlines regulations for partnerships or S corporations under common control to prevent avoidance of tax benefits through successor companies or other means, minimize compliance burdens for start-up companies, and recapture credits in cases of adjustments to payroll tax credits. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to the treatment of qualified small business credits and the allowance of a credit for research expenditures of qualified small businesses against FICA taxes. The text chunk explains the carryover of unused research credit for payroll taxes and the allocation of credit for controlled groups. The text chunk discusses the allocation of research expenses and payments for the research credit under section 41, with definitions provided for terms like "applicable calendar quarter." The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011, with appropriations to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Transfers from the general fund replicate the transfers that would have occurred without the amendments.
